  "body": "## Description\r\n\r\nThis PR adds the ability to edit feed URLs directly from the UI. Users can now click the edit button (✎) on any feed widget to update the feed URL, which automatically updates the feed name and site link.\r\n\r\n## Changes\r\n\r\n### Backend\r\n- Added `PUT /api/feeds/<feed_id>` endpoint for updating feed URLs and properties\r\n- Implemented validation to prevent duplicate feed URLs\r\n- Added CORS configuration for development\r\n- Updated port configuration to 5001 for development\r\n\r\n### Frontend\r\n- Added edit button to each feed widget\r\n- Implemented modal dialog for editing feed URLs\r\n- Added comprehensive error handling and validation\r\n\r\n### Testing\r\n- Added comprehensive tests for the new functionality\r\n- All existing tests continue to pass\r\n\r\n## Testing Notes\r\n- Backend tests require a running Redis service container\r\n- Dynamic port handling for Redis in CI environments\r\n- Environment variable `CACHE_REDIS_PORT` can override default Redis port\r\n\r\n## Deployment\r\n- Updated configuration for development environment\r\n- Maintains compatibility with existing production deployment\r\n\r\nThis feature allows users to easily update feed URLs when they change or need correction.",

    "body": "![high](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/high-priority.svg)\n\nThere's a performance issue here. The `fetch_and_update_feed` function internally calls `fetch_feed` again, which results in a redundant network request for the `new_url` that was already fetched on line 861.\n\nYou can avoid this extra network call by reusing the `parsed_feed` object and calling `process_feed_entries` directly, similar to how it's done in the `add_feed` endpoint.\n\n```suggestion\n        try:\n            if parsed_feed:\n                # Reuse the already fetched and parsed feed data to process entries,\n                # avoiding a redundant network call.\n                process_feed_entries(feed, parsed_feed)\n        except Exception as update_e:\n            # Log error during update but don't fail the operation\n            logger.error(f\"Error updating feed {feed.id} after URL change: {update_e}\", exc_info=True)\n```",

    "body": "![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)\n\nHardcoding the production API URL logic here is a bit brittle. It assumes the backend will always be available on the same host at port 5001.\n\nA more robust and standard approach for production is to use relative URLs (e.g., `/api/feeds`) and configure a reverse proxy (like Nginx or Caddy) on your server to route these requests to the backend service. This decouples the frontend from the specific backend port and location.\n\nFor development, you can keep the explicit URL.\n\n```suggestion\n    const API_BASE_URL = window.location.origin.includes('localhost') \n        ? 'http://localhost:5001' \n        : ''; // Use relative paths for production\n```",

current name of the feed.\n+     */\n+    function handleEditFeed(feedId, currentUrl, currentName) {\n+        console.log(`Editing feed: ${feedId}`);\n+        \n+        const modal = document.getElementById('edit-feed-modal');\n+        const feedIdInput = document.getElementById('edit-feed-id');\n+        const feedUrlInput = document.getElementById('edit-feed-url');\n+ currentUrl;\n+        feedNameInput.value = currentName;\n+        \n+        // Show the modal\n+        modal.classList.add('is-active');\n+    }\n+\n+    /**\n+     * Handles the submission of the edit feed form.\n+     * @param {Event} event - The form submission event.\n+     */\n+    async function handleEditFeedSubmit(event) {\n+        event.preventDefault();\n+        \n+        const modal = document.getElementById('edit-feed-modal');\n+        const feedIdInput = document.getElementById('edit-feed-id');\n+        const feedUrlInput = document.getElementById('edit-feed-url');\n+        const saveButton = document.getElementById('save-feed-button');\n+        \n+        const feedId = parseInt(feedIdInput.value);\n+        const newUrl = feedUrlInput.value.trim();\n+        const errorElement = document.getElementById('edit-feed-error');\n+        \n+        // Clear previous errors\n+        errorElement.style.display = 'none';\n+        \n+        if (!newUrl) {\n+            errorElement.textContent = 'Please enter a feed URL.';\n+            errorElement.style.display = 'block';\n+            return;\n+        }\n+        \n+        // Disable the save button and show loading state\n+        const originalButtonText = saveButton.textContent;\n+        saveButton.disabled = true;\n+        saveButton.textContent = 'Saving...';\n+        \n+        try {\n+            const result = await fetchData(`/api/feeds/${feedId}`, {\n+                method: 'PUT',\n+                headers: {\n+                    'Content-Type': 'application/json'\n+                },\n+                body: JSON.stringify({ url: newUrl })\n+            });\n+            \n+            if (result) {\n+                console.log('Feed updated successfully:', result);\n+                // Close the modal\n+                modal.classList.remove('is-active');\n+                \n+                // Update just the edited widget instead of reloading entire tab\n+                const widget = document.querySelector(`.feed-widget[data-feed-id=\"${feedId}\"]`);\n+                if (widget) {\n+                    // Replace the widget with updated content\n+                    const newWidget = createFeedWidget(result);\n+                    widget.replaceWith(newWidget);\n+                } else {\n+                    // Fallback: reload the tab if widget not found\n+ feed.');\n+            }\n+        } catch (error) {\n+            console.error('Error updating feed:', error);\n+        } finally {",

    "body": "![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)\n\nThe current error handling for a failed feed update is not very user-friendly. When an error occurs (e.g., the feed URL already exists), it's only logged to the console, and the user sees no feedback in the modal.\n\nYou should display the error message within the modal's error element (`edit-feed-error`) to inform the user what went wrong. The `error` object caught here contains a descriptive message from `fetchData`.\n\n```javascript\n        } catch (error) {\n            console.error('Error updating feed:', error);\n            const errorMsg = error.message || 'An unexpected error occurred.';\n            // Extract the backend message if available for a cleaner display.\n            const backendMsgIndex = errorMsg.indexOf('message: ');\n            errorElement.textContent = backendMsgIndex !== -1 \n                ? errorMsg.substring(backendMsgIndex + 9)\n                : errorMsg;\n            errorElement.style.display = 'block';\n        }\n```",
